articles.headline: Fed’s Issue on Rates: How Low?
articles.snippet: After a stunning cut one week ago, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.
articles.abstract: After a stunning cut one week ago, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Having stunned investors one week ago by unexpectedly slashing short-term interest rates, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.

articles.headline: Financial Ties Are Cited as Issue in Spine Study
articles.snippet: The testing of an artificial spinal disk provides a stark example of conflicts of interest among clinical researchers.
articles.abstract: The testing of an artificial spinal disk provides a stark example of conflicts of interest among clinical researchers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s most prominent spine surgeons hailed it as a medical breakthrough.

articles.headline: Bernanke’s Midterm Tests
articles.snippet: Sometime before Feb. 1, 2010, the next president will have to decide whether Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke should get a second term.
articles.abstract: Sometime before Feb. 1, 2010, the next president will have to decide whether Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke should get a second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Reserve has come to seem a bit like a Supreme Court justice  an unelected, unaccountable figure who wields power for years, regardless of who’s in the White House.

articles.headline: Pressure Mounts for Resignation at French Bank
articles.snippet: Politicians in France increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Politicians in France increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Senior politicians here increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for early Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: For a Change, New Jersey’s Primary Is at the Storm’s Center
articles.snippet: In New Jersey, Democrats are finding themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.
articles.abstract: In New Jersey, Democrats are finding themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLACKWOOD, N.J.  From the spectacle of a visit by a former president to the buzz of informal gatherings in living rooms and coffee shops across New Jersey, Democrats find themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.
articles.byline: By David Kocieniewski and David W. Chen

articles.headline: Overhaul, Make It a Venti
articles.snippet: After more than a decade of sensational buzz, Starbucks is struggling nationwide as it faces slowing sales growth and increased competition.
articles.abstract: After more than a decade of sensational buzz, Starbucks is struggling nationwide as it faces slowing sales growth and increased competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo.When a Starbucks moved in next door, the coffee fanatics who run the Broadway Cafe trembled. Sure, they roasted their own beans and served up handmade espresso drinks to a loyal clientele. But would it be enough to fight off a corporate behemoth?
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: McCain Defeats Romney in Florida Vote
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain won the biggest delegate prize so far in a closely contested primary. After finishing third, Rudolph W. Giuliani is likely to endorse Mr. McCain, officials said.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain won the biggest delegate prize so far in a closely contested primary. After finishing third, Rudolph W. Giuliani is likely to endorse Mr. McCain, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  Senator John McCain defeated Mitt Romney on Tuesday to win the delegate-rich Florida primary, solidifying his transformation to the Republican front-runner and dealing a devastating blow to the presidential hopes of Rudolph W. Giuliani.
articles.byline: By MICHAEL COOPER and MEGAN THEE

articles.headline: Dissident’s Arrest Hints at Olympic Crackdown
articles.snippet: The arrest of an activist who spread information about politically touchy topics is cited as an example of a “cleansing campaign.”
articles.abstract: The arrest of an activist who spread information about politically touchy topics is cited as an example of a “cleansing campaign.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  When state security agents burst into his apartment last month, Hu Jia was chatting on Skype, the Internet-based telephone system. Mr. Hu’s computer was his most potent tool. He disseminated information about human rights cases, peasant protests and other politically touchy topics even though he often lived under de facto house arrest.

articles.headline: When the Campaign Comes to New York, It’s a Tough Room but a Rich Prize
articles.snippet: With Florida behind them and 24 primaries looming, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with New York, where anything can happen to a campaign.
articles.abstract: With Florida behind them and 24 primaries looming, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with New York, where anything can happen to a campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Florida behind them and more than 20 primaries looming next Tuesday, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with a state where the Democratic governor’s popularity is in the gutter, the most powerful Republican is under federal investigation and the mayor of the largest city bolted not one but both political parties and has been mulling a presidential race himself.

articles.headline: Outside Groups Aid Obama, Their Vocal Critic
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama has denounced special-interest money, but is benefiting from millions of it nonetheless.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama has denounced special-interest money, but is benefiting from millions of it nonetheless.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of denouncing the influence of special-interest money in politics, Senator Barack Obama is nonetheless entering a critical phase of the presidential campaign benefiting from millions of dollars being spent outside campaign finance rules.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
articles.snippet: Fourteen firms are under scrutiny for possible accounting fraud, insider trading or other violations tied to loans made to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit.
articles.abstract: Fourteen firms are under scrutiny for possible accounting fraud, insider trading or other violations tied to loans made to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry, F.B.I. officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: For Giuliani, a Dizzying Free-Fall
articles.snippet: As Rudolph W. Giuliani ponders his political mortality, many observers point to the hubris and strategic miscalculations that plagued his campaign.
articles.abstract: As Rudolph W. Giuliani ponders his political mortality, many observers point to the hubris and strategic miscalculations that plagued his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps he was living an illusion all along.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Michael Cooper
